name: Spanner
overview:
This class allows you interact with Cloud Spanner.

First, install @google-cloud/spanner with npm:

$ npm install --save @google-cloud/spanner

If you are running your app on Google Compute Engine, you won't need to worry about supplying connection configuration options to @google-cloud/spanner— we figure that out for you.

However, if you're running your app elsewhere, you will need to provide project details to authenticate API requests.

Google Cloud Platform

var spanner = require('@google-cloud/spanner')();

Elsewhere

var spanner = require('@google-cloud/spanner')({ projectId: 'grape-spaceship-123', keyFilename: '/path/to/keyfile.json' });

The full set of options which can be passed to @google-cloud/spanner are outlined in our Authentication guide.

methods.name: Spanner
methods.description: Cloud Spanner is a highly scalable, transactional, managed, NewSQL database service. Cloud Spanner solves the need for a horizontally-scaling database with consistent global transaction and SQL semantics. With Cloud Spanner you don't need to choose between consistency and horizontal scaling — you get both.

methods.name: date
methods.description: Helper function to get a Cloud Spanner Date object.

params.name: value
params.description: • The date as a string or Date object.

methods.name: float
methods.description: Helper function to get a Cloud Spanner Float64 object.

params.name: value
params.description: • The float as a number or string.

methods.name: int
methods.description: Helper function to get a Cloud Spanner Int64 object.

params.name: value
params.description: • The int as a number or string.

examples.caption: If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: name
params.description: • The name of the instance to be created.

params.name: config.nodes
params.description: • The number of nodes allocated to this instance.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

params.name: callback.operation
params.description: • An operation object that can be used to check the status of the request.

exceptions.description: If a configuration object is not provided.

examples.caption: To control how many API requests are made and page through the results manually, set autoPaginate to false.
If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.

params.name: query.filter
params.description:
• An expression for filtering the results of the request. Filter rules are case insensitive. The fields eligible for filtering are:

    • name
    • display_name

    • labels.key where key is the name of a label

      Some examples of using filters are:

    • name:* The instance has a name.
    • name:Howl The instance's name is howl.
    • labels.env:* The instance has the label env.
    • labels.env:dev The instance's label env has the value dev.
    • name:howl labels.env:dev The instance's name is howl and it has the label env with value dev.

params.name: query.maxApiCalls
params.description: • Maximum number of API calls to make.

params.name: query.pageToken
params.description: • Token returned from a previous call, to request the next page of results.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request.

methods.name: getInstancesStream
methods.description: Get a list of spanner/instance objects as a readable object stream.

examples.caption: If you anticipate many results, you can end a stream early to prevent unnecessary processing and API requests.

params.name: options
params.description: • Configuration object. See spanner#getInstances for a complete list of options.

examples.caption: To control how many API requests are made and page through the results manually, set autoPaginate to false.
If the callback is omitted, we'll return a Promise.
